title: External Financial Reporting Decisions – Ultra Detailed Revision Edition
overview: External Financial Reporting Decisions (15%) forms the technical accounting backbone of Part 1. This section requires mastery of financial statement structure, recognition and measurement principles under US GAAP (including consolidated financial statements), analytical interpretation of reporting choices, and understanding of key differences between US GAAP and IFRS. The CMA exam emphasizes application — candidates must evaluate how accounting decisions affect earnings, cash flows, ratios, and long-term business decisions.
bulletNotes: Financial statements are fully interconnected — one transaction often affects multiple statements.
Net income is not the same as cash flow.
The indirect method of cash flows is heavily tested.
Inventory valuation impacts profitability, liquidity, and taxes.
Impairment testing differs significantly between GAAP and IFRS.
Revenue recognition timing affects earnings quality.
Deferred taxes arise from temporary (timing) differences only.
Lease accounting increases reported leverage under ASC 842.
Consolidated FS: Eliminate intercompany transactions. VIE = Risk/Reward model. Voting Interest = >50% ownership.
Goodwill is not amortized, but tested annually for impairment.
The equity method: dividends reduce the investment account, not income.
For GAAP impairment of assets held for use, step 1 uses undiscounted cash flows.
shortNotes: Begin with structural clarity: understand how each statement is built. Then focus on measurement rules (historical cost, amortized cost, fair value, NRV). Finally, connect accounting choices to financial ratios and performance evaluation. CMA questions frequently require tracing transaction impact across income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement. Master the indirect method adjustments and intercompany eliminations. Pay special attention to the new consolidation topic (VIE vs. voting interest) and the 5-step revenue model.

concepts.title: 1. Financial Statements – Structural & Analytical Foundation
concepts.content:
Purpose of Financial Reporting: To provide relevant and faithfully represented financial information useful to investors, creditors, and decision-makers.

Balance Sheet (Statement of Financial Position):
Reports assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific point in time.
Fundamental Equation: Assets = Liabilities + Equity.

Classification:
Current assets and liabilities are expected to be realized or settled within one year or the operating cycle (whichever is longer).

Income Statement:
Reports revenues and expenses over a period using accrual accounting.

Matching Principle: Expenses are recognized in the same period as related revenues.

Multi-step format includes:
Sales → COGS → Gross Profit → Operating Income → Income Before Tax → Net Income.

Statement of Changes in Equity:
Beginning Retained Earnings + Net Income − Dividends = Ending Retained Earnings.

Statement of Cash Flows:
Explains changes in cash using three sections: Operating, Investing, Financing.

Key Insight: Profitability (Net Income) and liquidity (Cash Flow) are different measures.

concepts.title: 2. Statement of Cash Flows – Indirect Method (Technically Accurate)
concepts.content:
The CMA exam frequently tests preparation and interpretation of the operating section using the indirect method.

Steps:

  1. Start with Net Income.
  2. Add back non-cash expenses (Depreciation, Amortization).
  3. Subtract gains and add losses from asset sales (these belong in investing).
  4. Adjust for changes in working capital.

Working Capital Adjustment Rules:

  • Increase in current asset → subtract.
  • Decrease in current asset → add.
  • Increase in current liability → add.
  • Decrease in current liability → subtract.

Important Clarification: Gains are subtracted from CFO because the full cash proceeds appear in Investing activities.

Free Cash Flow: CFO − Capital Expenditures.

Analytical Insight: Positive Net Income with negative CFO may indicate earnings quality issues.

concepts.title: 3. Revenue Recognition (ASC 606 – Corrected & Expanded)
concepts.content:
Core Principle: Recognize revenue when control of goods or services transfers to the customer.

The 5-Step Model:

  1. Identify the contract.
  2. Identify performance obligations.
  3. Determine transaction price.
  4. Allocate transaction price to performance obligations.
  5. Recognize revenue when (or as) performance obligations are satisfied.

Over Time Recognition Criteria (one must be met):

  • Customer simultaneously receives and consumes benefits.
  • Asset created is controlled by customer as created.
  • No alternative use and enforceable right to payment.

Variable Consideration: Estimated using expected value or most likely amount, constrained to avoid significant reversal.

Principal vs Agent: Principal records gross revenue; agent records net commission.

concepts.title: 4. Inventory – Measurement & Analytical Effects
concepts.content:
Inventory Cost Includes: Purchase price, freight-in, import duties.

Excludes: Freight-out (selling expense).

Cost Flow Methods (GAAP):

  • FIFO
  • LIFO
  • Weighted Average

IFRS Prohibits LIFO.

Lower of Cost or Market (GAAP LIFO/Retail):
Market = Replacement cost bounded by NRV and NRV minus normal profit margin.

IFRS: Always Lower of Cost or NRV.

LIFO Reserve: Difference between FIFO and LIFO inventory balances.

LIFO Liquidation: Occurs when older inventory layers are sold, artificially increasing income.

concepts.title: 5. Long-Lived Assets & Impairment (Correct GAAP Detail)
concepts.content:
Depreciation Methods: Straight-line, Units of Production, Declining Balance.

GAAP Impairment (Assets Held for Use):

  1. Recoverability Test: Carrying Value compared to Undiscounted Future Cash Flows.
  2. If not recoverable → Write down to Fair Value.

IFRS: Single-step impairment using Recoverable Amount (higher of Fair Value less costs to sell or Value in Use).

Reversal: Allowed under IFRS (except goodwill). Not permitted under GAAP for assets held for use.

concepts.title: 6. Investments & Financial Instruments (Correct Classification)
concepts.content:
Debt Securities:

  • Held-to-Maturity → Amortized Cost.
  • Trading → Fair Value with unrealized gains/losses in Net Income.
  • Available-for-Sale → Fair Value with unrealized gains/losses in OCI.

Equity Securities (GAAP):
Generally measured at Fair Value through Net Income unless equity method or consolidation applies.

Equity Method (20–50% ownership):
Record share of investee's net income as income; dividends reduce investment balance.

concepts.title: 7. Consolidated Financial Statements (New 2024 CSO Topic)
concepts.content:
Definition: Consolidated financial statements present the financial position and results of a parent and its subsidiaries as a single economic entity.

Two Consolidation Models:

ModelBasisWhen Used
Voting Interest ModelOwnership of >50% of voting sharesTraditional parent-subsidiary (majority ownership)
Variable Interest Entity (VIE)Power + Risk/Reward exposureEntity bears majority of risks/rewards even without majority ownership

Three Types of Consolidation Accounting:

  • Full Consolidation: 100% of subsidiary's assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses are combined with the parent's. Non-controlling interest (NCI) is reported separately in equity. Used when parent has control (>50% voting or VIE primary beneficiary).
  • Proportionate Consolidation: Only the parent's proportionate share of the investee's assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses is reported. Note: Generally NOT permitted under US GAAP (allowed under IFRS for joint ventures).
  • Equity Method: Investment reported as a single line on the balance sheet. Parent records its share of investee's net income. Used for significant influence (20-50% ownership).

Intercompany Eliminations (Critical):

  • All intercompany transactions must be eliminated in consolidation to avoid double-counting.
  • Eliminate: Intercompany sales/purchases, intercompany receivables/payables, intercompany loans and interest, intercompany dividends, unrealized profit on intercompany inventory transfers.
  • Example: If Parent sells $100,000 of goods to Subsidiary (still in Sub's inventory), eliminate $100,000 from both Sales and COGS, and remove any unrealized profit from inventory.

Goodwill: Arises when purchase price exceeds fair value of net identifiable assets acquired. Tested annually for impairment under GAAP (not amortized).

concepts.title: 8. Deferred Taxes – Correct Explanation
concepts.content:
Temporary Differences: Differences between book and tax basis that reverse in future periods.

Deferred Tax Liability (DTL): Future taxable amounts.

Deferred Tax Asset (DTA): Future deductible amounts.

Permanent Differences: Do not create deferred taxes.

Valuation Allowance: Required if it is more likely than not that DTA will not be realized.

concepts.title: 9. Lease Accounting (ASC 842 – Accurate)
concepts.content:
Under ASC 842, lessees recognize a Right-of-Use (ROU) Asset and Lease Liability for nearly all leases.

Finance Lease: Separate interest and amortization expense.

Operating Lease: Single straight-line lease expense.

Impact: Increases assets and liabilities, raising leverage ratios.

concepts.title: 10. GAAP vs IFRS – Accurate Comparison
concepts.content:
Inventory: LIFO prohibited under IFRS.

Impairment Reversal: Allowed under IFRS (except goodwill).

Revaluation Model: Allowed under IFRS for PPE and intangibles.

Development Costs: Capitalized under IFRS if criteria met; generally expensed under GAAP.

Cash Flow Classification: IFRS allows more flexibility for interest and dividends classification.

Consolidated FS: IFRS allows proportionate consolidation for joint ventures; GAAP does not.

formulas.name: Basic EPS
formulas.formula: (Net Income - Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Shares

formulas.name: Goodwill
formulas.formula: Purchase Price - Fair Value of Net Identifiable Assets

mistakes: Forgetting to remove gain from CFO.
Using discounted cash flows in GAAP recoverability test (Step 1 uses undiscounted).
Reversing impairment under GAAP (not allowed for assets held for use).
Capitalizing freight-out (it is a selling expense, not a product cost).
Confusing OCI items with Net Income items.
Forgetting to eliminate intercompany transactions in consolidation.
Thinking proportionate consolidation is allowed under US GAAP (it is not).
Confusing VIE model (risk/reward) with voting interest model (>50% ownership).
Recording dividends from equity method investee as income (they reduce the investment account).
Thinking all unrealized gains/losses on investments go to OCI (Trading and most equity securities go to Net Income).
Forgetting to eliminate unrealized profit in intercompany inventory transfers.
Misclassifying lease types under ASC 842 (focus on expense pattern, not just balance sheet).
Ignoring the valuation allowance for deferred tax assets.

quiz.question: If ending inventory is overstated, what is the effect?
options: COGS understated and net income overstated
quiz.explanation: Ending inventory overstated reduces COGS, which increases net income.

quiz.question: Under which model does a parent consolidate an entity when it bears the majority of risks and rewards?
quiz.explanation: The VIE model requires consolidation based on risk and reward exposure, not voting ownership.

quiz.question: What must be eliminated in consolidated financial statements?
quiz.explanation: All intercompany transactions (sales, receivables, payables, loans) must be eliminated to avoid double-counting.

quiz.question: Goodwill arises when:
options: FV of assets exceeds purchase price
Purchase price exceeds FV of net identifiable assets
quiz.explanation: Goodwill = Purchase Price - Fair Value of Net Identifiable Assets. The excess represents intangible value like brand and reputation.

quiz.question: Proportionate consolidation for joint ventures is allowed under:
quiz.explanation: US GAAP does not permit proportionate consolidation; IFRS allows it for joint ventures.

essay.question: Explain how LIFO vs FIFO affects financial statements and financial ratios during inflation. Additionally, describe the concept of intercompany eliminations in consolidated financial statements and why they are necessary.
essay.modelAnswer:
LIFO vs FIFO in Inflation:
In inflation, LIFO increases COGS (newer, higher costs flow to income) and reduces net income and taxes, lowering inventory and current ratio. FIFO reduces COGS (older, lower costs flow to income) and increases income and ending inventory, improving liquidity ratios but increasing tax liability.

Intercompany Eliminations:
When a parent company and its subsidiaries transact with each other (e.g., intercompany sales, loans, dividends), these transactions must be eliminated in consolidation. The consolidated entity is treated as a single economic entity — you cannot sell to yourself. Without elimination, revenues, expenses, assets, and liabilities would be double-counted, overstating the entity's financial position.

summary: Mastery of this section requires understanding financial statement mechanics, revenue timing (ASC 606), inventory measurement, impairment testing, lease accounting (ASC 842), deferred taxes, consolidated financial statements (VIE vs Voting Interest, intercompany eliminations), and GAAP vs IFRS differences. The CMA exam focuses on application and analytical consequences rather than memorization.

test.question: Which financial statement reports financial position at a specific point in time?
test.explanation: The Balance Sheet (Statement of Financial Position) reports assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific date.

test.question: The fundamental accounting equation is:
test.explanation: Assets = Liabilities + Equity is the foundation of the balance sheet.

test.question: Net income flows directly into:
test.explanation: Net income increases Retained Earnings on the statement of changes in equity.

test.question: Which is NOT a current asset?
test.explanation: Land is a long-term asset (PPE). Current assets are expected to be realized within one year.

test.question: Gross profit equals:
test.explanation: Gross Profit = Sales Revenue minus Cost of Goods Sold.

test.question: Discontinued operations are reported:
options: Net of tax below continuing operations
test.explanation: Discontinued operations are shown separately, net of tax, below income from continuing operations.

test.question: Which item bypasses Net Income and goes to OCI under GAAP?
test.explanation: Unrealized gains/losses on Available-for-Sale securities are reported in Other Comprehensive Income.

test.question: The multi-step income statement separates:
test.explanation: The multi-step format distinguishes operating income from non-operating gains/losses.

test.question: OCI items accumulate in:
test.explanation: OCI flows into Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income, a separate equity component.

test.question: Retained Earnings is directly reduced by:
test.explanation: Dividends reduce retained earnings. They are distributions to shareholders, not expenses.

test.question: The indirect method of calculating CFO starts with:
test.explanation: The indirect method begins with net income and adjusts for non-cash items and working capital changes.

test.question: Depreciation expense is treated as which adjustment in the indirect method?
test.explanation: Depreciation is a non-cash expense, so it is added back to net income to determine CFO.

test.question: An increase in Accounts Receivable is:
test.explanation: Higher AR means sales were recorded but cash was not collected — subtract from CFO.

test.question: An increase in Accounts Payable is:
test.explanation: Higher AP means expenses were recorded but cash was not yet paid — add to CFO.

test.question: A gain on sale of equipment is treated in CFO (indirect method) as:
test.explanation: Gains are subtracted from CFO because the full cash proceeds appear in investing activities.

test.question: Free Cash Flow equals:
test.explanation: Free Cash Flow = Cash Flow from Operations minus Capital Expenditures.

test.question: Purchase of equipment is classified as:
test.explanation: Buying long-term assets is an investing cash outflow.

test.question: Issuing common stock is classified as:
test.explanation: Issuing stock raises capital from owners — classified as financing.

test.question: Interest paid is classified under GAAP as:
test.explanation: Under US GAAP, interest paid is classified as an operating activity.

test.question: If inventory increases, the adjustment to CFO is:
test.explanation: An increase in inventory means cash was spent to buy inventory — subtract from CFO.

test.question: ASC 606 revenue recognition uses how many steps?
test.explanation: ASC 606 uses a 5-step model: Identify contract → Identify POs → Determine price → Allocate → Recognize.

test.question: A performance obligation must be:
test.explanation: Each performance obligation must be distinct — capable of being satisfied independently.

test.question: Variable consideration in ASC 606 must be:
test.explanation: Variable consideration is estimated and constrained to avoid significant revenue reversal.

test.question: A principal in a transaction records revenue at:
test.explanation: A principal controls the good/service and records the full (gross) transaction price as revenue.

test.question: An agent in a transaction records revenue at:
test.explanation: An agent arranges for another party to provide the good/service and records only its commission.

test.question: Revenue recognized over time requires meeting at least:
test.explanation: If at least one of the three over-time criteria is met, revenue is recognized over time.

test.question: Contract assets represent:
options: Revenue earned but not yet billed
test.explanation: A contract asset exists when the entity has satisfied a PO but does not yet have an unconditional right to payment.

test.question: Contract liabilities represent:
test.explanation: Contract liabilities (deferred revenue) arise when payment is received before the PO is satisfied.

test.question: IFRS prohibits which inventory method?
test.explanation: IFRS does not allow LIFO. Only FIFO, Weighted Average, and Specific Identification are permitted.

test.question: During inflation, FIFO results in:
test.explanation: FIFO uses older, lower costs for COGS → lower COGS → higher gross profit → higher net income.

test.question: During inflation, LIFO results in:
options: Higher COGS and lower net income
test.explanation: LIFO uses newer, higher costs for COGS → higher COGS → lower gross profit → lower net income.

test.question: LIFO Reserve equals:
test.explanation: LIFO Reserve = FIFO Inventory value minus LIFO Inventory value.

test.question: LIFO liquidation occurs when:
test.explanation: LIFO liquidation happens when sales exceed purchases, causing older, lower-cost layers to be sold, inflating income.

test.question: Freight-in is classified as:
test.explanation: Freight-in is a cost of acquiring inventory and is included in the product cost.

test.question: Freight-out is classified as:
test.explanation: Freight-out is a delivery/selling expense, not a product cost.

test.question: Lower of Cost or NRV applies under:
test.explanation: Both frameworks require inventory to be written down when its value declines (GAAP uses LCM for LIFO, LCNRV otherwise).

test.question: COGS equals:
test.explanation: COGS = Beginning Inventory + Purchases (net) - Ending Inventory.

test.question: If ending inventory is understated, net income will be:
test.explanation: Understated ending inventory → overstated COGS → understated net income.

test.question: The GAAP impairment test (Step 1) for long-lived assets uses:
test.explanation: Step 1 (recoverability test) compares carrying value to undiscounted future cash flows.

test.question: If the recoverability test is failed under GAAP, the asset is written down to:
test.explanation: Step 2 writes the asset down to fair value when the recoverability test fails.

test.question: IFRS impairment uses the higher of:
options: Fair value less costs to sell or Value in Use
test.explanation: IFRS Recoverable Amount = higher of Fair Value less costs to sell OR Value in Use (discounted cash flows).

test.question: Can impairment losses be reversed under US GAAP for assets held for use?
test.explanation: US GAAP prohibits reversal of impairment losses on assets held for use.

test.question: Which depreciation method results in higher early-year expense?
test.explanation: Double declining balance (accelerated) produces higher depreciation in early years.

test.question: Goodwill under GAAP is:
options: Tested annually for impairment, not amortized
test.explanation: Under GAAP, goodwill is not amortized but tested annually for impairment.

test.question: Trading securities unrealized gains are reported in:
test.explanation: Trading securities are marked to fair value with unrealized gains/losses flowing through net income.

test.question: Available-for-Sale securities unrealized gains are reported in:
test.explanation: AFS unrealized gains/losses are reported in Other Comprehensive Income.

test.question: The equity method applies when ownership is approximately:
test.explanation: 20-50% ownership typically conveys significant influence, requiring the equity method.

test.question: Under the equity method, dividends received from the investee:
test.explanation: Dividends received reduce the investment balance (they are a return of investment, not income).

test.question: Held-to-Maturity securities are measured at:
test.explanation: HTM securities are held until maturity and reported at amortized cost.

test.question: A temporary difference between book and tax creates:
test.explanation: Temporary differences create deferred tax assets or liabilities that reverse in future periods.

test.question: Permanent differences between book and tax create:
test.explanation: Permanent differences never reverse, so they do not create deferred tax assets or liabilities.

test.question: A DTA is reduced by a:
test.explanation: A valuation allowance reduces a DTA if it is more likely than not that it will not be realized.

test.question: Municipal bond interest is an example of a:
test.explanation: Municipal bond interest is tax-exempt — included in book income but never in taxable income (permanent).

test.question: Tax depreciation exceeding book depreciation creates a:
test.explanation: Higher tax depreciation creates a future taxable amount (DTL) when the difference reverses.

test.question: Under ASC 842, most leases create:
options: A ROU asset and lease liability
test.explanation: ASC 842 requires lessees to recognize a Right-of-Use asset and corresponding lease liability.

test.question: A finance lease expense pattern is:
test.explanation: Finance leases have separate interest (declining) and amortization expense, resulting in higher total expense in early years.

test.question: An operating lease expense under ASC 842 is:
test.explanation: Operating leases recognize a single straight-line lease expense over the lease term.

test.question: Lease capitalization increases reported:
test.explanation: Recognizing lease liabilities on the balance sheet increases total liabilities and leverage ratios.

test.question: IFRS allows impairment reversal for:
test.explanation: IFRS permits impairment reversal for all assets except goodwill.

test.question: The revaluation model for PPE is allowed under:
test.explanation: IFRS permits upward revaluation of PPE to fair value; GAAP uses historical cost only.

test.question: Development costs under IFRS are:
test.explanation: IFRS allows capitalization of development costs when specific criteria are met (technical feasibility, intent to complete, etc.).

test.question: Under IFRS, interest paid can be classified as:
test.explanation: IFRS provides flexibility — interest paid can be classified as operating or financing.

test.question: Consolidated financial statements present the parent and subsidiaries as:
test.explanation: Consolidation combines the parent and subsidiaries into one economic entity for financial reporting.

test.question: The Voting Interest Model requires consolidation when ownership of voting shares exceeds:
test.explanation: The Voting Interest Model typically requires consolidation when ownership exceeds 50% of voting shares.

test.question: The Variable Interest Entity (VIE) model is based on:
test.explanation: VIE consolidation is based on who has the power to direct activities and bears the majority of risks/rewards.

test.question: Full consolidation includes what percentage of the subsidiary's assets and liabilities?
test.explanation: Full consolidation combines 100% of the subsidiary's assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses.

test.question: Non-controlling interest (NCI) in full consolidation is reported in:
test.explanation: NCI represents the portion of equity not owned by the parent and is reported as a separate component of equity.

test.question: Proportionate consolidation is generally NOT permitted under:
test.explanation: US GAAP does not allow proportionate consolidation. IFRS allows it for joint ventures.

test.question: Which intercompany item must be eliminated in consolidation?
test.explanation: Intercompany receivables and payables must be eliminated to avoid double-counting.

test.question: Unrealized profit on intercompany inventory transfers is:
test.explanation: If inventory sold between entities remains unsold to third parties, the unrealized profit must be eliminated.

test.question: Goodwill in consolidation equals:
options: Purchase price minus FV of net identifiable assets
test.explanation: Goodwill = Purchase Price paid for subsidiary minus Fair Value of its net identifiable assets.

test.question: Intercompany dividends from subsidiary to parent are:
test.explanation: Intercompany dividends are eliminated because you cannot pay dividends to yourself as a single entity.

test.question: The primary beneficiary of a VIE must:
options: Have power and absorb majority of losses/returns
test.explanation: The primary beneficiary has the power to direct VIE activities and absorbs majority of risks/rewards.

test.question: Under the equity method, the investor records its share of investee's net income as:
test.explanation: The investor increases the investment account and recognizes its proportionate share as investment income.

test.question: Ending cash balance appears on which statements?
options: Both balance sheet and cash flow statement
test.explanation: Ending cash appears on the balance sheet (as cash asset) and at the bottom of the cash flow statement.

test.question: Dividends declared are classified as a(n):
test.explanation: When dividends are declared, a liability (Dividends Payable) is created. They are NOT expenses.

test.question: Revenue is recognized under accrual accounting when:
test.explanation: Under ASC 606, revenue is recognized when (or as) control of the promised good/service transfers to the customer.

test.question: The Statement of Changes in Equity reconciles:
options: Changes in equity components including RE
test.explanation: It shows changes in RE, common stock, APIC, treasury stock, and AOCI during the period.

test.question: Assets are reported at the measurement basis defined by:
test.explanation: Different assets use different bases: historical cost, fair value, amortized cost, NRV — per applicable GAAP/IFRS guidance.

test.question: Inventory errors affect:
options: Both balance sheet and income statement
test.explanation: Inventory errors impact COGS (income statement) and ending inventory (balance sheet).

test.question: Positive Net Income with negative CFO may indicate:
test.explanation: When income is positive but operating cash flow is negative, it raises questions about earnings quality (aggressive accruals).

test.question: Under GAAP, dividends received are classified in the cash flow statement as:
test.explanation: Under US GAAP, dividends received from investments are classified as operating activities.

test.question: A decrease in prepaid expenses results in:
test.explanation: A decrease in a current asset (prepaid) → add to CFO (cash was previously paid, now being expensed).

test.question: A decrease in unearned revenue results in:
test.explanation: Decrease in a current liability (unearned revenue) → subtract from CFO (cash was received earlier, now recognized as revenue).

test.question: Weighted Average cost method:
options: Is prohibited under both GAAP and IFRS
test.explanation: Weighted Average calculates a single average cost for all units available for sale.

test.question: NRV (Net Realizable Value) equals:
options: Estimated Selling Price – Costs to Complete and Sell
test.explanation: NRV = Estimated Selling Price minus Estimated Costs of Completion and Disposal.

test.question: Straight-line depreciation allocates cost:
test.explanation: Straight-line allocates an equal amount of depreciation expense each year.

test.question: Units of Production depreciation is based on:
test.explanation: Units of Production allocates depreciation based on actual usage, making expense proportional to output.

test.question: An asset held for sale is measured at:
options: Fair value less costs to sell
test.explanation: Assets held for sale are reported at the lower of carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell.

test.question: Under GAAP, which of the following is a non-cash item added back in the indirect method?
test.explanation: Amortization is a non-cash expense that reduces net income but does not use cash — add back.

test.question: Basic EPS equals:
options: (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares
test.explanation: Basic EPS = (Net Income – Preferred Dividends) ÷ Weighted Average Common Shares Outstanding.

test.question: Treasury stock is:
test.explanation: Treasury stock is a company's own shares repurchased. It reduces total equity (contra-equity).

test.question: The matching principle requires:
options: Cash receipts matched to cash payments
Expenses recognized in the same period as related revenues
test.explanation: The matching principle ensures expenses are recorded in the period they help generate revenue.

test.question: Accrued expenses are:
test.explanation: Accrued expenses are obligations for services/goods received but not yet paid for (current liability).

test.question: Prepaid expenses are classified as:
test.explanation: Prepaid expenses represent future economic benefits paid in advance — current asset.

test.question: GAAP uses a two-step impairment test for:
test.explanation: Long-lived assets held for use undergo Step 1 (recoverability) then Step 2 (write-down to FV) if needed.

test.question: Debt-to-Equity ratio equals:
test.explanation: Debt-to-Equity = Total Liabilities ÷ Total Equity. Measures financial leverage.

test.question: Current Ratio equals:
test.explanation: Current Ratio = Current Assets ÷ Current Liabilities. Measures short-term liquidity.

test.question: Goodwill impairment under GAAP results in:
options: A write-down to fair value (loss recognized)
test.explanation: When the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, goodwill is written down (impairment loss).

test.question: The qualitative characteristics of useful financial information include:
test.explanation: The FASB Conceptual Framework identifies Relevance and Faithful Representation as the two fundamental qualitative characteristics.
